Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Preoperative Flow Assessment in Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting

Background: This study aimed to assess the effect of preoperative physiological flow assessment on mid-term outcomes in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

Methods: This observational nationwide cohort study included 18,211 patients who underwent first-time isolated CABG in Sweden from 2013 to 2020, identified from the SWEDEHEART registry. The primary outcome was the incidence of all-cause mortality, stroke, new myocardial infarction, new coronary angiography, and new revascularization, measured over a median follow-up of 3.6 years. The study did not involve randomisation or blinding.

Results: Of the total cohort, 2,869 patients (15.8%) underwent preoperative flow assessment, with an increase from 7.1% in 2013 to 21.5% in 2020. Patients with flow assessment were younger, had a lower EuroSCORE II, and received fewer distal anastomoses (3.0 ± 0.9 vs 3.2 ± 1, P < .001). There were no significant differences in mortality, post-discharge myocardial infarction, or stroke between groups. However, preoperative flow assessment was associated with a higher risk of new angiography (adjusted hazard ratio [aHR] 1.32, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.08–1.62, P = .008) and new revascularization (aHR 1.55, 95% CI 1.18–2.04, P = .002) more than two years after CABG.

Interpretation: Preoperative flow assessment did not improve clinical outcomes and was associated with increased risk for new angiography and revascularization after two years. These findings suggest that the use of flow assessment with current cut-off levels may not be applicable in CABG, and further studies are warranted.

Trial registration: Not applicable.

Funding: Not specified.
